awd_titl_txt: Investigation of Pore Pressure Migration During Piezocone Tests
awd_abstract_narration:
The piezocone dissipation test, where an instrumented cone is advanced through the soil column, is used throughout geotechnical engineering, environmental engineering, and other groundwater-related fields. The test is routinely used to characterize how easily water seeps through soil (i.e. soil permeability) which is necessary for engineering analyses such as predicting rate of soil consolidation settlements or predicting contaminant transport by groundwater seepage. However, methods for interpreting these tests are limited due to several major simplifying assumptions. The test is performed by advancing the cone through the soil column and measuring porewater pressures at the cone shoulder, then pausing penetration and recording how porewater pressures change. Soil deformations around the penetrating cone induce an excess porewater pressure field in saturated soil. Then when penetration is paused, excess porewater pressures are recorded over time as they dissipate to hydrostatic conditions in a dissipation curve. Available methods to interpret soil permeability from dissipation curves assume that: (i) excess porewater pressure migration is horizontal, and (ii) measured porewater pressure decay to hydrostatic conditions is monotonic. However, there is a significant dataset of non-monotonic piezocone dissipation tests, where measured excess porewater pressure initially increases then decreases to hydrostatic conditions, which may be due to vertical excess porewater pressure migration. This project will investigate and characterize the causes of non-monotonic piezocone dissipation tests, which will lead to improved piezocone dissipation interpretation methods and more accurate characterization of soil permeability from the test data. The project also includes demonstrations at K-12 engineering outreach events to increase the engagement of Portland, Oregon grade school students with civil engineering concepts.

The objective of this project is to characterize the mechanisms that contribute to non-monotonic piezocone dissipation curves with a numerical piezocone model. This project hypothesizes that vertical and horizontal excess porewater pressure migration contribute to non-monotonic piezocone dissipation curves. It is also hypothesized that those contributions are affected by soil stress history (i.e. over-consolidation ratio), soil properties, hydraulic conductivity anisotropy, and penetration drainage conditions. These hypotheses will be tested with numerical simulations of piezocone dissipation in saturated clay using a direct axisymmetric penetration model and the MIT-S1 constitutive model. The simulations will investigate: (i) the role of soil stress history and soil properties on excess porewater pressure distribution around the penetrating cone and subsequent dissipation curves, (ii) the role of vertical and horizontal porewater pressure migration on dissipation curves, (iii) the impact of hydraulic conductivity anisotropy on vertical and horizontal porewater pressure migration, and (iv) how the above factors are affected by partial drainage conditions during penetration. The results of these analyses will be synthesized to suggest interpretation methods for non-monotonic dissipation tests and to re-interpret existing non-monotonic dissipation tests.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes

The piezocone (CPTu) dissipation test is used to characterize how loads on soil transfer from the pore fluid to the soil particles. This load transfer is characterized by the coefficient of consolidation. CPTu dissipation tests are performed by penetrating an instrumented cone through the soil at a constant rate, then pausing the cone and monitoring how pore water pressures at the cone change over time. The coefficient of consolidation is estimated from the rate that pore water pressures return to static conditions and from other soil properties including the soil rigidity index. Interpretation is relatively straightforward for standard CPTu dissipation tests where excess pore water pressures continually decrease to static conditions, however, a large subset of CPTu dissipation tests are non-standard with excess pore water pressures initially increasing before decreasing to static conditions. Interpretation of non-standard tests is challenged by a limited understanding of what causes the non-standard response. Additionally, current methods for interpreting the coefficient of consolidation from standard and non-standard CPTu dissipation tests have several notable sources of uncertainty. The objective of this study was to investigate CPTu dissipation tests and therefore improve both standard and non-standard CPTu dissipation test interpretation. There were three aspects of CPTu dissipation tests that this study focused on: (1) investigating the role of horizontal and vertical pore water pressure migration during CPTu dissipation tests, (2) studying what causes non-standard CPTu dissipation tests, and (3) examining the sensitivity of interpreted coefficient of consolidation to the estimated value of the soil’s rigidity index. The study was performed with a numerical cone penetration model that simulated undrained cone penetration in clay to steady state penetration conditions, then simulated pore water pressure around a paused cone. The simulations were performed for a clay with over consolidation ratios of 1, 2 and 4; and for porewater dissipation with various ratios of the vertical and horizontal hydraulic conductivities. The results indicate that CPTu dissipation test interpretation may overestimate the horizontal coefficient of consolidation by not accounting for vertical pore water pressure migration. The study also demonstrated that non-standard dissipation tests are likely caused in part by vertical pore water pressure migration from the cone tip to the cone shoulder (where pore water pressures are measured) and that this effect is more substantial as the over consolidation ratio increases. The interpreted coefficient of consolidation is relatively insensitive to the method for estimating rigidity index. 

CPTu dissipation tests and the coefficient of consolidation are used throughout Civil and Environmental Engineering to estimate the rate that pore fluid flows through soil and the rate that a structure's load will transfer from pore fluid to soil. In engineering practice, the coefficient of consolidation is required to estimate soil resistance and settlement over time and may be used to estimate water seepage rates through soil. The results of this study will be used to improve interpretation of CPTu dissipation tests, and therefore reduce uncertainty in the estimated coefficient of consolidation. As part of this project, STEM outreach were performed as part of programming for Oregon Mathematics Engineering Science Achievement (MESA), including at a STEM open house and for a recorded lesson introduction to a middle school class.

 


Last Modified: 12/15/2021
Modified by: Diane Moug
